doc.previous: In mid-2004, entrepreneur Sean Parker (an informal advisor to Zuckerberg) became the company's president.[25] In June 2004, Facebook moved its operations base to Palo Alto, California.[22] It received its first investment later that month from PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel.[26] In 2005, the company dropped the from its name after purchasing the domain name facebook.com for US$200,000.[27]
doc.after: In May 2005, Accel partners invested $12.7 million in Facebook, and Jim Breyer[28] added $1 million of his own money. A January 2009 Compete.com study ranked Facebook the most used social networking service by worldwide monthly active users.[29] Entertainment Weekly included the site on its end-of-the-decade "best-of" list, saying, "How on earth did we stalk our exes, remember our co-workers' birthdays, bug our friends, and play a rousing game of Scrabulous before Facebook?"[30]
